text: (birds chirping)

- Right now I'm standing in
my kitchen, drinking coffee.
When I think about the future
I think people will be on the moon

in a smart city that
was created by robots.
Drinking coffee,

maybe video conferencing
with people on Mars.
How do you do that?

It's not enough just
having the electronics.
It needs to have a human feel to it.
We're still humans, even in the future.

And we need to be able
to have connections.
I think that's the future.
And it's coming much sooner than we think.

- [Astronaut] Are you getting
a picture now, Houston?

- [Astronaut] It's different,
but it's very pretty out here.

- So growing up, I had no
interest in technology.
There was no internet, there was no email.

And now technology is just
part of everything that we do.

People are talking to each
other all across the world.
We're natural explorers.

So we will go to foreign places
to answer the big questions.

And the question now is,
what's outside of our world?
(dynamic music)
- [Narrator] We have come a long way,

but man's journey into
space has just begun.
- My name is Tom Soderstrom.

I am a technologist, and
an engineer, and futurist.
For the last 14 years

I was chief technology
and innovation officer
at NASA's jet propulsion laboratory.

And that really meant trying
to figure out the technology

that's coming in the
next four to five years.
And put that in the hands of scientists
that find new worlds.

But JPL, they ask the
really big questions.
Are we alone?
Where did we come from?
Where is the universe going?

Is there life on Mars,
or Europa, or Titan?
How do we get there?
(rocket whooshing)
30 years ago,

it was a rare event that
a spacecraft was launched.

There were only a few superpowers
that launched spacecraft.
Today, in terms of cost,
the barriers to entry are coming down.
It's about a 15th to launch a spacecraft.
A 20th to build it.
A third to track the spacecraft.
And we get 100 times more data.
And it's 100 times cheaper to process it.

So the real barrier to
entry here is access.

And that's where cloud
computing becomes important
because you can put all the data together
where people can access it.
(mystical music)
Data is abundant.

We estimate that we currently
have 40 zettabytes of data.
In 2025, we'll have 175 zettabytes.
If you translate it to a human population

it's 1.7 megabytes created
by every human per second.
99% of that is not analyzed.

It's estimated that 30%
of it will go on the cloud
where it will be accessible by everybody.

Access to the cloud is really
the democratization of space.

In the future, we'll put
thousands of satellites
in space to provide internet access
to underserved or unserved countries.

All the new participants
that we've never seen
in the space industry will now get access.
So I expect that we will get

a tremendous amount of
innovation coming soon.
And that's really exciting.

- [Narrator] The greatest
service any science performs,
therefore its most practical aspect,

is what it adds to
man's fund of knowledge.

The knowledge of ourselves
and the world we live in.

- Sharing goes all the way
back to our beginnings.
We are storytellers, we love a good story.
And hearing a good story
from somebody you admire is the ultimate.

And that's what science is
all about, sharing data.
So let me give you an example.

A few years ago, we had an
earthquake in California.
The earthquake happens.

A bunch of computers start up
automatically with the cloud.
And it's taking satellite images

and creates an interferogram
of the ground shift.

So we then have a picture
of the earth deformation.
How did it change?
JPL posted out the results.

There was a person who was
interested in earthquake faults.

He saw those satellite images,
and detected a new fault,
and published that out.

Which is so exciting because
somebody creates something,

publishes it, somebody
builds on that, publishes it.

And we're now standing on
the shoulders of giants
in minutes, not years like we did before.
Today, you can be a space scientist
without owning anything at all.

All you have is your laptop
at home, or your tablet,
or your smartphone, and the cloud.

The citizen scientist is
able now to not have to worry

about having a PhD in AI,
or being a data expert,

but just use the data that
other people have created.

So people can apply their
expertise and passion.
(dynamic music)
That's why innovation could be
so much faster than it was before.
- [Narrator] Science has broken the chains

that for centuries shackled
humans to the planet Earth.

- If we look back at big
economies in history,

you had the farming economy
where everybody was spread out.
You had the industrial economy,

everything was manual
labor, and it was hard work.

The next economy is the
future space economy.

Simply put, it's new
technologies that are accessible
and lower barriers to entry for everyone.

Meaning more people will
be interested in space.

These new people will become
innovators of the future.

The trappings of an innovator
is that they are curious,

they are not satisfied
with the status quo,
and they are reaching to do something
even beyond what you're asking.

They will need some
gray hairs to guide them
to avoid the big missteps.
One of my passions is mentoring.
- My name is Lini Mestar.
I immigrated to the United States in 2007.
I had no English background.
No, didn't know anything.
I met Tom initially as a mentor

and he was my supervisor
when I first started JPL.
Today, I'm a senior researcher
at NASA's jet propulsion laboratory.

A lot has happened since
the last time we talked.
A lot of breakthroughs

throughout all the projects
that we've been working on.
Yeah, for example,

the lunar flashlight project
is getting ready to launch.
- Congratulations, that's a big deal.
- Thank you, thank you.

- It's actually gonna,
your thing is gonna fly.
That's something to tell you parents.
- To the moon.
Yep, for the first time, to the moon.
- That's pretty cool.

What about that other
one you're working on,
the space born computer?

- Yeah, so I actually--
- Smaller?

- Yeah, so I actually
just got a patent on it.

- Did you really?
- Yeah.
So it finally happened.
And this is it.

- Not only are you the
first one to go to college,

but the first one to get a
patent within your family.
- Absolutely, yeah.

- Fantastic, congratulations.
- Thank you, Tom.
- That is you is truly incredible.
- Thanks Tom, I appreciate it.
Without you it wouldn't have happened.
- At this stage of my life

I'm able to see an innovator
before they see themselves,

and give them the opportunity
to exceed and excel.
And startups are really the key here

'cause today's startups is
tomorrow's huge company.
It's a very ripe opportunity for startups.
So what are you working on these days?
What's your, what are you excited about?
- We're hiring like crazy.

We've got a really, really
talented engineering team
behind us, including some old JPLers
that you're familiar with.
We just got our third patent granted.

- Good mentorship is not just
saying, hey, you're wonderful.

But is to point out when
somebody does something wrong

and say, hey, you
could've done this better.
And here's what I recommend next time.

I don't think people need to
be managed, they need to be led

to what is the goal and
how do they achieve it.

I just try to create the
opportunities for them.
- Tom, thank you so much for everything
that you've done for me.
After a long and storied career

where you were at JPL
doing incredible things,
playing with new technologies.
What comes after that?
It's not riding off into the sunset.

- [Narrator] Many men here on
Earth helped ready the systems

which would take a few
men across that frontier.
- I had a great career at JPL
and accomplished a lot of fun things.
The new innovators were in place.
All the new technologies were there.
But I wanted to do one more adventure.

MARS stands for machine
learning, automation,
robotics, and space.

So it's the biggest areas
that impact our future.
And it still is.

The vision behind MARS was
really to invent the future
and have people come together
from these different disciplines.
'Cause a lot of innovation happens
in the border between the disciplines.
The intent is to focus on the technologies
that can help the public sector
move forward in this future space economy,

just like the commercial sector
does for the public good.
And give people access to data
where they can look at it themselves.

Today we are in Amazon's
quantum computing lab
in partnership with Caltech.
Quantum computing is very different
than traditional computing.
And it has the promise of running faster
than traditional computers.
A computer does things serially.

A quantum computer does
many things at once.

So you get much higher
performance, but it's difficult.
It's very complicated.
It's in its beginning stages.
Quantum computing holds a lot of promise,

but how do we actually
understand what it can do?
Only by testing it.
So you can test both hardware,
the software, we have simulators.

They can try it all by only
changing one line of code.

And you can use many
different quantum computers
without having to own them.
Now there is a lot of computer powers.
We're getting a lot of data.

And that's the promise
of quantum computing.

The only way we're really
gonna realize the benefits
of the future of innovation is to share.
And sharing is use the data,
publish the results and the data,
and put it out so other people can use it.

And we're seeing that happen
over, and over, and over.
There are a lot of startups,
there are a lot of governments,

there are a lot of universities,
and citizen scientists,

and data scientists, and
machine learning experts,
that are all using each other's data.

So we're pushing the boundary
farther and farther out.

And all of a sudden you
can do so much more.
(mysterious music)
- [Narrator] Scientists use this method
for a deeper purpose,

to gain an understanding of
the world in which we live.
- Science questions itself all the time.

We need to question
ourselves all the time.
We have now massive amounts of data,

zettabytes and zettabytes
worth of data, to question.
It's no longer an opinion.
It can be a theory.
And opinion gets a lot of sway.
Science will help by looking at the data,

form your theory, and then
seeing if that theory holds true
by just continuously questioning it.
So I hope and think that we will get

all the citizen scientists
across the world,
invent new ideas of how to use this data.
(gentle music)
I also care very deeply about our earth.

And I think if there's
one thing we need to solve
it's global climate change.

We need to solve it for our
children and their children.
And it needs to become a focus.
Every country is affected.
Looking at data from space
you get a very different perspective.

There's no doubt that the
ice sheets are melting.
I think we'll see a lot of investment in
being carbon neutral and carbon negative.
We need companies to take carbon

out of the atmosphere
and reduce it quickly.
The good news is the future is here.
There are companies creating satellites,
trying to protect Mother Earth,
and measure things like water.

And they will be looking
at the water table
all the way down to reservoirs.
And it'll help predict, from space,
floods, hurricanes, and natural disasters.
More and more and more.
There already is a company in Australia
that is reducing the water usage by 95%.

There's another company that
is able to take all the data
and find forest fire within two minutes.
(jaunty music)

- [Narrator] A look at the
future, looks good, eh?

- The best way to predict
the future is to create it.
And I really believe in that.
All of us are now co-creating the future.

Learning and being curious is
what moves humanity forward.

And that's what's gonna
move us forward in space.
Curiosity about where is there life.
Curiosity about robots.

Could I make this robot
hop over that ditch?
How would I do that?

All the successful
innovators that I've seen
are curious people.
They're just wondering, why not?
So what are we limited by?
It's not data.
It's not compute power.
It's simply imagination.
(dynamic music)
